## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-12-31T17:49:58Z
## Message ID: 20221231-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2022-12-31T16:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2022-12-27T17:05Z (see notifications 20221227-AL-003 and 20221229-AL-001) are likely caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2022-12-24T02:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20221224-AL-003, 20221225-AL-002), detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-12-26T00:33Z (see notification 20221226-AL-001), with additional influence from the coronal hole high speed stream that arrived on 2022-12-24, and further possible influence from the coronal hole high speed stream that arrived on 2022-12-29. The current sustained solar wind speed is around 600 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-12-27T17:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, STEREO B, Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-12-30T20:14:15Z
## Message ID: 20221230-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2022-12-30T16:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~811 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 31 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -3/-14 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-12-30T16:53:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, STEREO B, and Mars (minor impact).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Solar Orbiter at 2023-01-02T12:53Z, STEREO A at 2023-01-02T09:05Z, STEREO B at 2023-01-01T22:34Z, and Mars at 2023-01-04T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-01-02T00:06Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2022-12-30T16:53:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20221230_214600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2022-12-30T16:53:00-CME-001) is associated with M1.4 flare from AR13176 (N19E08) with ID 2022-12-30T15:24:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2022-12-30T15:28Z. This analysis is preliminary and additional updates may be made. 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2022-12-29T11:40Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2022-12-27T17:05Z are likely caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2022-12-24T02:48:00-CME-001 (notifications 20221224-AL-003, 20221225-AL-002), detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-12-26T00:33Z 
(see notification 20221226-AL-001), with additional influence from the coronal hole high speed stream that had arrived on 2022-12-24. The maximum sustained solar wind speed observed at L1 was just above 700 km/s and the current solar wind speed is around 440 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-12-27T17:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 21, 2022 - December 27, 2022
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-12-28T19:24:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2022-12-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2022-12-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20221228-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 3 M-class flares (see list below). There were 2 O-type CMEs and 12 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact Missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-12-24T02:48Z  NASA Missions Near Earth at 2022-12-27T08:00Z (glancing blow), maximum Kp index 2-4 (below minor) 
                   see notifications 20221224-AL-003, 20221225-AL-002
2022-12-24T08:36Z  NASA Missions Near Earth at 2022-12-28T00:00Z (glancing blow), maximum Kp index 2-3 (below minor)
                   see notification 20221224-AL-004

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-12-21T04:48Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-12-24T06:00Z and STEREO A at 2022-12-24T10:00Z
2022-12-24T02:48Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-12-26T15:29Z, Mars at 2022-12-29T04:00Z, STEREO A at 2022-12-27T00:00Z, STEREO B at 2022-12-27T14:00Z (see notifications 20221224-AL-003, 20221225-AL-002)
2022-12-24T08:36Z   STEREO B at 2022-12-27T20:00Z (see notification 20221224-AL-004)
2022-12-26T00:12Z   Juno at 2023-01-12T00:00Z (see notification 20221226-AL-002)
2022-12-26T06:00Z   Juno at 2023-01-12T00:00Z (see notification 20221226-AL-002)

An ensemble was created for the CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-12-24T02:48Z with 24 members. The CME was estimated to reach NASA Missions near Earth between about 2022-12-26T01:37Z and 2022-12-27T01:03Z (average arrival 2022-12-26T12:03Z) for 54% of simulations. The full results can be found here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-12-24_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX162/Detailed_results_20221224_054100_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX162.txt (see notification 20221225-AL-002). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-12-26T00:33Z and at STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2022-12-26T08:00Z (see notification 20221226-AL-001). This arrival signature is still under analysis.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period 2022-12-26T12:00Z-15:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was likely caused by the arrival of the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-12-24T02:48Z associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-12-26T00:33Z (see notification 20221226-AL-001). In addition, the interplanetary shock may have been associated with a strong compression of the magnetosphere. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2022-12-27T04:54Z (see notifications 20221227-AL-001 and 20221227-AL-002).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-12-24T14:05Z. The elevated energetic electron flux levels were likely caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which started on 2022-12-22, reaching a maximum sustained speed of approximately 685 km/s (see notifications 20221224-AL-001 and 20221224-AL-002). The energetic electron flux subsided to background levels on 2022-12-26. Later on, the electron flux was elevated and crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu again starting at 2022-12-27T17:05Z. This second elevation may have been associated with the arrival of the aforementioned CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-12-24T02:48Z with additional influence from another coronal hole high speed stream arrival observed on 2022-12-24 and associated with an interplanetary shock observed in DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-12-23T19:21Z (see notification 20221227-AL-003). The solar wind speed is currently around 520 km/s.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-12-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-01-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently five numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13176 (N19E40) produced 2 M-class flares and Active Region 13169 (N22W70) produced one M-class flare during the reporting period. These Active Regions may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. At least two unnumbered Active Regions located around latitudes N20 and S20 are expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO and STEREO A.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels throughout the outlook period. As seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO, a coronal hole currently centered around N30W15 may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2022-12-30. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is currently elevated near the threshold level of 1000 pfu and may remain elevated through the beginning of the outlook period. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-12-27T18:20:56Z
## Message ID: 20221227-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2022-12-27T17:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2022-12-24T02:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20221224-AL-003, 20221225-AL-002). The possible arrival of this CME was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-12-26T00:12Z (see notification 20221226-AL-001). This arrival signature is still under analysis.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-12-27T17:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 
Note that the GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux had reached one point above 1000 pfu earlier this morning at 2022-12-27T11:30Z and then dipped below the threshold until more recently. Prior to this, the energetic electron fluxes had remained slightly elevated after the previous RBE event with ID 2022-12-24T14:05:00-RBE-001 (see notifications 20221224-AL-001, 20221224-AL-002), most likely associated with a coronal high speed stream on 2022-12-22.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-12-27T13:56:54Z
## Message ID: 20221227-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was possibly close to the geosynchronous orbit today starting at 2022-12-27T04:54Z (notification 20221227-AL-001).

This strong compression of the magnetosphere may be associated with a prolonged period of negative Bz this morning, which followed the likely arrival at L1 of the O-type CME first detected by SOHO at 2022-12-24T02:48Z (notifications 20221224-AL-003 and 20221225-AL-002). The associated Interplanetary Shock with ID 2022-12-26T00:33:00-IPS-001 was observed by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-12-26 (see notification 20221226-AL-001). 

The analysis of this signature is still ongoing.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2022-12-27T04:54:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2022-12-24T02:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20221224-AL-003). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A, STEREO B, and Mars. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2022-12-25T22:57Z and 2022-12-27T05:03Z (average arrival 2022-12-26T10:32Z) for 75% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2022-12-26T04:52Z and 2022-12-26T21:54Z (average arrival 2022-12-26T13:29Z) for 25% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2022-12-27T10:22Z and 2022-12-28T12:15Z (average arrival 2022-12-27T22:06Z) for 45% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-12-26T01:37Z and 2022-12-27T01:03Z (average arrival 2022-12-26T12:03Z) for 54% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 84% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2022-12-24T14:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which started on 2022-12-22. The current high speed stream reached a maximum sustained solar wind speed of 600 km/s. The solar wind observed at L1 is currently around 550 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-12-24T14:05:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 34 M-class flares, 7 O-type CMEs, and 8 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, the following CME impacts were estimated:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-12-15T13:23Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2022-12-16T02:00Z (see notification 20221215-AL-001)
2022-12-18T06:48Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-12-22T04:00Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2022-12-19T06:00Z (see notification 20221218-AL-001)
2022-12-19T03:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-12-22T20:13Z
2022-12-19T12:00Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-12-22T20:13Z

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2022-12-19T03:00Z-06:00Z. Analysis is ongoing, but this enhancement of geomagnetic activity may have been associated with the combined arrival of a coronal mass ejection and a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-12-19. An associated interplanetary shock was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-12-18T19:52Z (see notification 20221218-AL-002), as well as a predicted magnetopause crossing to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2022-12-19T07:15Z (see notifications 20221219-AL-001 and 20221219-AL-002). 

Additionally, the STEREO A IMPACT instrument detected an interplanetary shock around 2022-12-18T14:44Z. This arrival may have been associated with the same combined CME and coronal hole high speed stream arrival at L1 mentioned above.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to increased flaring and CME activity (see details below).

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-12-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-12-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate to high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently six active regions on the Earth-facing disk. Most of the flaring activity (at least 29 of the M-class flares) seen throughout the reporting period originated from Active Region 13165 which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2022-12-18. Additional high flaring activity was seen from Active Region 13169 (N21E32) which produced 4 of the M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to show higher level flaring activity throughout the outlook period. Active Regions 13166 (S08W82), 13163 (S19W70), 13170 (S20E37), and 13171 (N24E48) have produced C-level flaring activity throughout the reporting period and may continue flaring in the next week. The activity was also very high on the farside as seen by the extensive list of CMEs (see list above). This activity can continue for the next several weeks. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at minor levels throughout the outlook period. There may be enhancements in geomagnetic activity due to small coronal holes seen across the northern hemisphere of the Earth-facing disk. The first of these coronal holes, located near N20W45, may become geoeffective within the next 48 hours. Additional coronal holes are currently centered around N03W03 and N15E20, the former of which may become geoeffective on or around 2022-12-25. Current enhancements in the solar wind parameters appear to be indicative of flux rope signatures, however no candidate CMEs have been found to associate with the signatures due to the limited imagery available at this time. Analysis is still ongoing.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 14 C-type CMEs and 5 O-type CMEs (see list below).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2022-12-07T12:00Z-15:00Z. This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-12-07. An associated interplanetary shock was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-11-07T08:46Z (see notification 20221207-AL-001). The maximum sustained solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR at L1 reached approximately 600 km/s on 2022-12-08. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was enhanced at the beginning of this reporting period due to a threshold crossing during the previous reporting period beginning at 2022-12-01T14:15Z. This enhancement was caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2022-11-30 (see notifications 20221203-AL-001, 20221205-AL-001, and 20221207-AL-002). The energetic electron flux levels subsided to background levels late on 2022-12-07 and remained at background levels for the remainder of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-12-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-12-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate to high levels for the upcoming reporting period. There are currently 11 numbered active regions on the Earth facing disk.  Active Region 13163 (S20E18) and Active Region 13153 (S15W95), which has rotated off the Earth-facing disk, have produced almost 10 M-class flares on 2022-12-14, some of which are associated with CMEs. These Active Regions may continue to exhibit flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, there is an unnumbered Active Region visible on the STEREO A northeastern limb which may rotate onto the Earth facing disk by 2022-12-15. On the backside, the CME activity was high (see list above), and this may continue throughout the upcoming reporting period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to minor during the outlook period. There are several coronal holes seen in the SDO imagery. The first one is a southern coronal hole which reached the central meridian on 2022-12-13 and may become geoeffective on or around 2022-12-19. The second one is currently located around N18E45.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 3 O-type CMEs and 4 C-type CMEs(see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CME starting on 2022-12-01T07:48Z may affect Mars at 2022-12-04T22:02Z, Solar Orbiter at 2022-12-03T03:34Z, STEREO A at 2022-12-03T12:42Z, and STEREO B at 2022-12-03T09:37Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-12-03T09:37Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index was 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notifications 20221201-AL-001 and 20221201-AL-002). An ensemble with 48 members was also performed and it predicted that the CME would reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-12-03T09:19Z and 2022-12-04T01:11Z (average arrival 2022-12-03T17:17Z) for 12% of simulations.  The full details can be found at: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-12-01_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX161/Detailed_results_20221201_074800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX161.txt (see notification 20221201-AL-004). This CME arrival may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-12-04T12:09Z.  This arrival is still under analysis. 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact: 

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-12-03T18:00Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2022-12-04T22:00Z (see notification 20221203-AL-002)
2022-12-04T01:25Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2022-12-05T03:00Z (see notification 20221204-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2022-11-30T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2022-12-01T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight enhancement of the geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2022-11-30.  The solar wind speed reached maximum values of 700 km/s on 2022-12-02.  

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-12-01T14:15Z and has remained elevated for the whole reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival on 2022-11-30 described above (see notifications 20221203-AL-001 and 20221205-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A, STEREO B, and Mars. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2022-12-03T12:01Z and 2022-12-03T15:45Z (average arrival 2022-12-03T13:53Z) for 4% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2022-12-03T09:19Z and 2022-12-04T01:39Z (average arrival 2022-12-03T17:08Z) for 12% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2022-12-04T21:36Z and 2022-12-05T17:27Z (average arrival 2022-12-05T06:44Z) for 8% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-12-03T09:19Z and 2022-12-04T01:11Z (average arrival 2022-12-03T17:17Z) for 12% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 78% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

## Notes:
This CME event (2022-12-01T07:48:00-CME-001) is also predicted to arrive at Solar Orbiter around 2022-12-03T03:34Z, based on previous heliospheric modeling (see previous notification 20221201-AL-002).

This CME event (2022-12-01T07:48:00-CME-001) is associated with M1.0 flare with ID 2022-12-01T07:04:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2022-12-01T07:21Z.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-11-29T13:55Z (see notification 20221129-AL-002). The most recent crossing of the 1000 pfu threshold was at 2022-11-30T07:05Z and the fluxes are currently elevated but below the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream that arrived at L1 on 2022-11-27 (see notification 20221128-AL-001), reaching a maximum sustained speed of approximately 700 km/s. The solar wind observed at L1 is currently around 550 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-11-29T13:55:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2022-12-01T07:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20221201-AL-001).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, and STEREO B.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Mars at 2022-12-04T22:02Z, Solar Orbiter at 2022-12-03T03:34Z, STEREO A at 2022-12-03T12:42Z, and STEREO B at 2022-12-03T09:37Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-12-03T09:37Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
   

Updated CME parameters are:

Start time of the event: 2022-12-01T07:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~1306 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 17/27 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-12-01T07:48:00-CME-001
